text: Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: You know whether we’ve completely treated a couple of men and now we’re waiting to go up or whether or not we’re ready to go right now. So that would be a slot availability. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Your thoughts or questions about that? Patient: Well you’re going to coordinate with Dr. G. Doctor: I will coordinate with him the sort of the decision about have you progressed. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then I’ll print out these consent forms for you that you can take and sort of that he can look at as well. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And it’s a diagnosis you’ll carry and you’re we don’t - not really out of the woods for five or ten years. Family Member: And then when you say not cured, if the cancer will come back would those people be considered to be in remission? Doctor: So if, so when we get his PSA undetectable and finished therapy, he’s in remission. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Even so on the hormones. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Uhm and you’re in remission unless it recurs, comes back. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Last question, or uh maybe not. Mistletoe. I’ve had some friends that have said maybe that can help with side effects, things of that nature. If I were to research that, would that in any way – Doctor: Yeah, well thanks for asking that, so mistletoe is contraindicated certainly during chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it interferes with chem. I would say also during radiation.

text: Patient: I don’t have to go and come back next week. Doctor: Okay. All right, well then, so you know what we can do then if you're if you're comfortable. Let me make sure that we went over everything too because Patient: I’m comfortable. That’s the way I am. Doctor: Let me go, let me just make sure you're a volunteer. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Yeah, your participation will obviously not affect your clinical care. We're going to collect biospecimens as part of this so your blood, you can find this study online. We talked about the muscadine grape skin and that we don't know for sure if this works or not, that's why we're testing it and obviously we follow your PSA. So yeah, so 80 people total are going to be in it. Alright, so the first part that we need to do this pre screening is and we do need you to sign is to get the blood test drawn to see if you're eligible for it. So if you're agreeable to at least that part then we can do that today. Okay, all right. So this means that this at least then you won't be charged for the test. Do you want that? Patient: Yes. Family Member: So how long is this? I mean once we starts it. What will they do? Doctor: So you come back every month, and we’ll see you initially- you report any side effects. And the way that this usually works is that well, for any treatment, we continue the treatment until either disease progression, meaning that your disease is getting worse despite the treatments of the treatments not working anymore, or unacceptable toxicity. So if you have really bad side effects, we're not going to continue the treatment. Patient: Right. Doctor: So this Yeah, so this one is talking about your risks of discomfort. The most common one is gassiness. So you might not be the most pleasant person to be around while you're taking this, but that's, I mean, it's only 8%. So it's not really that common, but most people usually do fine there. Been no serious side effects. So, you know, it's very safe for us it doesn't cost anything there are no extra costs it's just what would be done in normal clinical care anyways is what they've done anything that would be extra that's like not covered by insurance like this blood test, to check your genotype it’s covered by the study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You don't get paid to join the study, you can leave at any time to protect your privacy, you do tend to get parking tickets, so that like you know, when you come visits okay and then these are the this is the contact information for our clinic.

text: Family Member: That class, is that here? Or is that a web cast? Doctor: No, it’s here. Family Member: It’s here. Patient: Any need for a driver - chemo days, things like that? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So, on chemo days, you have to have a driver. Ummm. You may not need him. But, I mean, my sense is that if you start getting sick and nauseated, and I have to give you a medicine that’s sedating - I don’t want you getting behind the wheel of a car and driving home. Patient: Oh sure Doctor: But, if you don’t have any nausea, we have done everything that we needed to do and you feel great, you’ve got company to talk about – Hey, that wasn’t so bad. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: But, yeah, uh, you’ve gotta have a partner on those days. Patient: That’s fine. Just wanted to Doctor: There is no need to stay. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: T_ may be able to do it all in one day. I’m not a big fan of all in one day. Uh, just because, uh, it’s got a lot of hoops, and if you don’t have it. So, tend to see you on a Tuesday. Is everything clear? And, then we pick a day and you just go and get it. Patient: Alright. Doctor: And then that day, the people upstairs have cleared it for you. Your, uh, counts are okay. That your time is upstairs is shortened because - - Patient: I won’t have to wait for results. Doctor: Correct. Patient: Now is it possible to get the pre and/or post treatments at a local or local - Healthcare Professional: The draw? Patient: LabCorp or Quest or something? Doctor: Yes, absolutely. Patient: Okay. ‘Cuz I don’t mind comin’ down obviously, but if I can shave a couple hours out of a day- Doctor: Yeah. If you on a Monday, went over to LabCorp, got your blood tests, awesome. Tuesday, we clear you, and if you want Wednesday or Thursday to be your chemo day, you just tell me.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then, hopefully, you’ll be able to tolerate that dose from an anemia perspective, uh, until the next set of scans, and we can give this drug a bit more time to work, as you put it, and I agree with that. Patient: Um hum. Okay. I think we’re on the same page. Doctor: Comfortable with that? Patient: I am. Doctor: More importantly, is your wife comfortable with that?

text: Family Member: Yeah so we’d be on two clinical trials? Doctor: Well this one you’ll just be in follow-up. You won’t be actively on this particular one. Family Member: So the Xtandi… Doctor: So you’ll be off active treatment from our current clinical trial because you’ve progressed technically. Patient: So I wouldn’t be part of that clinical trial? Doctor: You’d still be part of it for follow-up reasons but not actively on. So you wouldn’t get the Xtandi from this particular clinical trial Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: anymore. Which… Patient: Just a second, even with the BET1? Doctor: No. For the BET1 that study will then kick in you’ll be registered to that study and they will give you from that study they will give you the Xtandi and the BET medication. Patient: Because ten thousand dollars a month is not something… Doctor: Well that’s okay. We can find ways around it and getting it covered if we need to. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
